title: Evolution in a big city - Jason Munshi-South

options.label: A
options.text: Rivers

options.label: B
options.text: Streams

options.label: C
options.text: Seeping water from the ground

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The urban mice have become genetically different from their country ancestors due to adaptation to the city environment

options.label: B
options.text: The genetic changes would have no effect on their ability to adapt to the city environment

options.label: C

multiple-choice.question: **Evaluation**: What is the significance of the speaker's research on the urban mice, in terms of its broader implications?

options.label: B

title: How containerization shaped the modern world - Sir Harold Evans

multiple-choice.question: What experience as a truck driver in 1937 led Malcolm McLean to conceive the idea of containerization?

options.label: A
options.text: He was frustrated with the long lines at the truck stop.

options.label: B
options.text: He observed the inefficiencies of break bulk shipping while waiting for his cargo to be loaded onto a ship.

options.label: C
options.text: He had a conversation with a fellow truck driver about the inefficiencies of shipping.

options.label: D
options.text: He was delayed due to traffic congestion on the highway.

multiple-choice.question: What traditional method of shipping general non-bulk cargo did Malcolm McLean observe and seek to improve?

options.label: A
options.text: Container shipping

options.label: B
options.text: Break bulk shipping

options.label: C
options.text: Bulk cargo shipping

options.label: D
options.text: Intermodal transportation

multiple-choice.question: How did Malcolm McLean's idea of containerization impact the shipping industry?

options.label: A
options.text: It increased the cost of shipping goods and reduced global trade.

options.label: B
options.text: It significantly reduced the time it took to load and unload cargo, making global trade more efficient and cost-effective.

options.label: C
options.text: It had a minimal impact on the shipping industry, only saving a few days in transit time.

options.label: D
options.text: It led to a decrease in the variety of goods available in the market.

options.label: A
options.text: Ideal X

options.label: B
options.text: Container Express

options.label: C
options.text: Global Trader

options.label: D
options.text: Sea Cargo

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: International trade

options.label: C
options.text: Globalization

options.label: D
options.text: Economic integration

options.label: B
options.text: 10 years

options.label: C
options.text: 19 years

options.label: D
options.text: 25 years

options.label: A
options.text: Reduced labor costs for stevedores

options.label: B
options.text: Increased security for the cargo

options.label: C
options.text: Time savings for truck drivers and shipping companies

options.label: D

title: The power of simple words - Terin Izil

multiple-choice.question: In the story of "The Wizard of Oz," what phrase does Dorothy repeat to return home?

options.label: A
options.text: "There's no place like home."

options.label: B
options.text: "No coordinates exist like one's domicile."

options.label: C
options.text: "Home is where the heart is."

options.label: D
options.text: "Follow the yellow brick road."

multiple-choice.question: According to the text, what is a potential drawback of using complex vocabulary in writing?

options.label: A
options.text: It can make the writing more engaging and memorable.

options.label: B
options.text: It can help writers showcase their expertise and sophistication.

options.label: C
options.text: It can be ineffective if not understood by the target audience.

options.label: D
options.text: It can increase the writer's credibility and authority.

multiple-choice.question: What strategy does the author suggest writers use to compete for attention in a crowded market?

options.label: A
options.text: Use more complex vocabulary to stand out and impress readers.

options.label: B
options.text: Write longer, more detailed pieces to engage readers and provide value.

options.label: C
options.text: Use concise language to get to the point quickly and efficiently.

options.label: D
options.text: Use emotional appeals to persuade readers.

multiple-choice.question: According to the author, what is happening to the attention span of younger generations?

options.label: A
options.text: It is increasing due to improved focus and concentration.

options.label: B
options.text: It is remaining steady across generations.

options.label: C
options.text: It is decreasing due to various distractions.

options.label: D
options.text: It is only affected by the type of content consumed.

multiple-choice.question: What approach does the author suggest writers take when writing for a captive audience?

options.label: A
options.text: Use more complex vocabulary to impress the audience.

options.label: B
options.text: Write at a level significantly higher than the audience's expectations.

options.label: C
options.text: Write at a level that meets the audience's expectations and needs.

options.label: D
options.text: Use a formal tone to establish authority.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's view on using repetitive language in writing?

options.label: A
options.text: It is an effective way to engage the reader and reinforce key points.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a necessary evil in some cases, such as technical writing.

options.label: C
options.text: It can be a sign of poor writing and lack of creativity.

options.label: D
options.text: It is not a concern in most cases.

multiple-choice.question: How does the author suggest writers avoid using repetitive language?

options.label: A
options.text: Use a thesaurus to find more complex words and phrases.

options.label: B
options.text: Write at a higher reading level to showcase expertise.

options.label: C
options.text: Vary their language and use concise descriptions.

options.label: D
options.text: Use longer sentences to convey more information.

multiple-choice.question: Why does the author emphasize the importance of knowing the audience in writing?

options.label: A
options.text: It is not important, as writers should always use complex vocabulary.

options.label: B
options.text: It is only important in certain cases, such as technical writing.

options.label: C
options.text: It is crucial to tailor the writing to the audience's needs and expectations.

options.label: D
options.text: It is not necessary, as writers should always write at a high level.

multiple-choice.question: What strategy does the author recommend for writers working with limited space?

options.label: A
options.text: Use more complex vocabulary to convey their message.

options.label: B
options.text: Write longer, more detailed pieces to engage the reader.

options.label: C
options.text: Use concise language to get to the point quickly and efficiently.

options.label: D
options.text: Use shorter sentences to simplify the message.

multiple-choice.question: What is the author's humorous suggestion for writers who want to use complex words?

options.label: A
options.text: Use a dictionary to find more complex words and phrases.

options.label: B
options.text: Write at a higher reading level to showcase expertise.

options.label: C
options.text: Use a thesaurus to find more complex words and phrases.

options.label: D
options.text: Save their money and buy a Scrabble board instead.

title: Symbiosis: A surprising tale of species cooperation - David Gonzales

multiple-choice.question: What is symbiosis in biology?

options.label: A
options.text: A process where one species adapts to its environment.

options.label: B
options.text: A partnership between two different species, where both depend on each other.

options.label: C
options.text: A relationship between two species where one is a predator and the other is prey.

options.label: D
options.text: A competition between two species for resources.

multiple-choice.question: Which species provides seeds to the other in the symbiosis between the Clark's nutcracker and the whitebark pine?

options.label: A
options.text: The Clark's nutcracker provides seeds to the whitebark pine.

options.label: B
options.text: The whitebark pine provides seeds to the Clark's nutcracker.

options.label: C
options.text: Both species provide seeds to each other.

options.label: D
options.text: Neither species provides seeds to the other.

multiple-choice.question: How do Clark's nutcrackers gather seeds from whitebark pine cones?

options.label: A
options.text: By gnawing the cones from the upper branches.

options.label: B
options.text: By picking apart the cones with their powerful beaks.

options.label: C
options.text: By using their pouch in their throat to store the seeds.

options.label: D
options.text: By flying over the forest and collecting seeds from the ground.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the Clark's nutcracker's pouch in its throat?

options.label: A
options.text: To store seeds for the winter.

options.label: B
options.text: To carry the seeds to the forest floor.

options.label: C
options.text: To pick apart the whitebark pine cones.

options.label: D
options.text: To cache the seeds an inch under the soil.

multiple-choice.question: How do Clark's nutcrackers remember where they cache their seeds?

options.label: A
options.text: By using landmarks on the landscape, such as trees, stumps, and rocks.

options.label: B
options.text: By using their sense of smell to locate the seeds.

options.label: C
options.text: By using their beaks to dig up the seeds.

options.label: D
options.text: By storing the seeds in a specific pattern on the forest floor.

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of the symbiosis between the Clark's nutcracker and the whitebark pine?

options.label: A
options.text: The Clark's nutcracker gets seeds to eat, and the whitebark pine gets protection from other animals.

options.label: B
options.text: The Clark's nutcracker replants the whitebark pine trees, and the whitebark pine provides seeds to the Clark's nutcracker.

options.label: C
options.text: The Clark's nutcracker gets protection from other animals, and the whitebark pine gets protection from the Clark's nutcracker.

options.label: D
options.text: The Clark's nutcracker and the whitebark pine have no benefit from each other.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of how the Clark's nutcracker and the whitebark pine have evolved to suit each other?

options.label: A
options.text: The Clark's nutcracker has developed long, tough beaks for extracting seeds from cones.

options.label: B
options.text: The whitebark pine has developed branches that sweep upwards with the cones at the very ends.

options.label: C
options.text: Both A and B are correct.

options.label: D
options.text: Neither species has evolved to suit the other.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of squirrels in the symbiosis between the Clark's nutcracker and the whitebark pine?

options.label: A
options.text: They help to replant the whitebark pine trees.

options.label: B
options.text: They help the Clark's nutcracker to find the seeds.

options.label: C
options.text: They gnaw the cones from the upper branches so they fall to the ground.

options.label: D
options.text: They have no role in the symbiosis.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the symbiosis between the Clark's nutcracker and the whitebark pine?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a rare example of a symbiotic relationship between two species.

options.label: B
options.text: It is an important part of the ecosystem in the mountains of Wyoming and Montana.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a unique relationship between two species that has been studied extensively.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a competition between two species for resources.

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of the symbiosis for the ecosystem as a whole?

options.label: A
options.text: The Clark's nutcracker and the whitebark pine provide food for other animals.

options.label: B
options.text: The Clark's nutcracker and the whitebark pine help to maintain the balance of the ecosystem.

options.label: C
options.text: The Clark's nutcracker and the whitebark pine have no benefit for the ecosystem.

options.label: D
options.text: The Clark's nutcracker and the whitebark pine are a threat to the ecosystem.

title: How simple ideas lead to scientific discoveries - Adam Savage

options.label: B
options.text: Inertia

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B
